subject: probability
title: Beta Distribution
contentHtml: The Beta distribution is a continuous probability distribution defined on the interval [0,1]. It's often used as a conjugate prior in Bayesian inference and has numerous applications in machine learning.

workedExample.problemHtml: Suppose we have a dataset of user preferences for two products. We want to model the probability that a user prefers product A over product B.

steps.mathHtml: \[\alpha = \text{number of users preferring A}, \beta = \text{number of users preferring B}\]
steps.explanation: We need to specify the number of users with each preference.
We use the Beta distribution to model the user preferences.

intuition: The Beta distribution is a flexible model for continuous random variables on the interval [0,1]. It's particularly useful when modeling proportions or probabilities.

subject: probability
title: Beta Distribution
contentHtml: The beta distribution is a continuous probability distribution defined on the interval [0,1]. It's often used as a conjugate prior in Bayesian inference.

workedExample.problemHtml: Suppose we have a coin with an unknown bias. We observe the outcome of 10 flips, and it's heads 7 times.

steps.explanation: We use Bayes' theorem to update the prior with the likelihood of observing 7 heads out of 10 flips.

intuition: The beta distribution captures our uncertainty about a probability value, and it's particularly useful when we have limited data.
realWorldApplications: In natural language processing, the beta distribution can be used to model the prior distribution of word frequencies.

title: Beta Distribution
contentHtml: The beta distribution is a continuous probability distribution defined on the interval [0,1]. It's often used as a conjugate prior in Bayesian inference.

workedExample.problemHtml: Suppose we have a random variable X that represents the proportion of positive reviews for a new product. We want to model this distribution.

steps.explanation: We need to specify the values of \alpha and \beta.
We can use the beta distribution as our prior since it's defined on [0,1].

intuition: The beta distribution is useful when modeling proportions or percentages. It's also a conjugate prior for binomial data.
realWorldApplications: In natural language processing, the beta distribution can be used to model the proportion of positive/negative sentiments in text.
